results.title: Bruce McGuinness in Melbourne
results.brief_description: In the late 1960s and early 70s, the Black Power movement emerged from cities and suburbs around Australia. Activist, Koori leader and filmmaker Bruce McGuinness helped strengthen the intersection of activism and filmmaking with his politically charged Black Fire (1972).
results.description: In the late 1960s and early 70s, the Black Power movement emerged from cities and suburbs around Australia. It was “the most exciting and dynamic era in modern Indigenous history” according to historian and Aboriginal activist Professor Gary Foley, who gained widespread attention for protests during the period. Fellow activist, Koori leader and filmmaker Bruce McGuinness helped strengthen the intersection of activism and filmmaking with his politically charged Black Fire (1972).
description_for_label: In the late 1960s and early 70s, the Black Power movement emerged from cities and suburbs around Australia. It was “the most exciting and dynamic era in modern Indigenous history” according to historian and Aboriginal activist Professor Gary Foley, who gained widespread attention for protests during the period. Fellow activist, Koori leader and filmmaker Bruce McGuinness helped strengthen the intersection of activism and filmmaking with his politically charged Black Fire (1972).

results.title: Bruce Dawe
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, SBS-TV, Robin Hughes and Linda Kruger
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian biography”.
An intimate encounter with the extraordinary “poet of suburbia”, Bruce Dawe, whose ability to evoke the drama and beauty of everyday life has set him amongst the most accessible and highly regarded of Australian poets. His highly empathic style of writing stems from a staggered history of variant occupations, contact with those from a diversity of backgrounds and failed studies as he drifted through his early years with a skill for writing but little direction. Here his motivations and writing process as they have since stood are explored. He discusses his family history and early life, his fascinations and motivations and his view of his place in the poetry world of giving a voice to ordinary Australians. Through interviews with Dawe, footage of him reading his poetry and commentary on his life and writing this is a comprehensive personal insight into Bruce Dawe’s life and influences.

results.title: Bruce almighty
results.creator_credit: Universal Pictures, Spyglass Entertainment, Tom Shadyac and Jim Carrey
results.brief_description: Local tv reporter Bruce Nolan doesn’t think that the world is treating him fairly. Then, after the worst day ever, Bruce angrily rails against God for ruining his life and mismanaging the universe. So God responds and endows Bruce with all of his powers to see if he can do a better job. Cast includes Jim Carrey, Morgan Freeman, Jennifer Aniston, Philip Baker Hall, Catherine Bell.

results.title: Brown wolf
results.creator_credit: International Cinemedia Center, Learning Corporation of America and George Kaczender
results.brief_description: Adaptation of a Jack London story spotlighting the conflict between the call of the wild and civilization. A man attempts to shoot his dog in order to survive, but the dog escapes and is taken in by a young couple. Eventually the man returns and claims his dog, which chooses to return to the wild. Set in the early 1900’s. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Brown rot
results.creator_credit: Shell Film Unit, Stephen Ackroyd and J.V. Durden
results.brief_description: Shows the nature and extent of the fruit disease know as “brown rot”. Illustrations include initial infection of the fruit; development of the mycelium and fruit bearing bodies, conidiophores; growth rings found in the affected areas of the fruit; transfer of the disease from fruit to fruit.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Shell Film Unit, Stephen Ackroyd and J.V. Durden

results.title: Brown men and red sand
results.creator_credit: South Australian Government Tourist Bureau and C Mountford
results.brief_description: This film is part of the original silent film record of C.P. Mountford’s Central Australian journey with a group of desert Aborigines. From the original footage the two popular sound films, “Walkabout” and “Tjurunga”, were compiled. “Brown men and red sand” (if projected at silent speed) shows the movements of the Aborigines, especially in the sequences dealing with tribal ceremonies and dances, more naturally than in the sound films, where the movements look jerky.

results.title: Brown coal to kilowatts
results.creator_credit: State Electricity Commission of Victoria and Frank Hurley
results.brief_description: Classroom film describing the processes by which wet, raw brown coal from the Yallourn open cut is burned in specially designed boilers to produce steam for use in turbines for the generation of electric power. Laboratory demonstration, models, and diagrams explain the principles of operation of plant seen in use at Yallourn.

results.title: Brown coal to briquettes
results.creator_credit: State Electricity Commission of Victoria and Frank Hurley
results.brief_description: Classroom film showing the manufacture of briquettes at Yallourn and Morwell Victoria. Includes demonstration by models of processes; operation of coal dredges at open cut; crushing and drying of coal; pressing of fine powder into briquettes; transport of finished product to other parts of Victoria.
